A week ago I was tinkering with deriving normativity from systems theoretic principles, and landed on the following insight:

> Evil is a self-maintaining system that not only harms but reproduces the representational projections that make the harm non-legible.

Feeling pretty vindicated rn.

reply_context.text:
I found that this is wrong. Democracy actually is a powerful motivating force for a critical slice of the population *if they perceive a real threat*.

I call this the "legibility" theory of democratic backsliding: the more legible the threat, the more likely it is to prompt effective pushback.

posts.text:
Conversely, I could have a very tight group of close friends, and feel very little loneliness despite my network being small.

Whether or not a loneliness epidemic exists might be affected by network topology, but ultimately this is about psychology. Focusing on SNA is asking the wrong question. 8/8

reply_context.text: Loneliness is an emotion. It's not a mathematical property of my social network structure, it's a quality of my subjective experience. I can have lots of shallow friendships and be socially active, and still have a subjective experience of deep loneliness. 7/n

posts.text: Loneliness is an emotion. It's not a mathematical property of my social network structure, it's a quality of my subjective experience. I can have lots of shallow friendships and be socially active, and still have a subjective experience of deep loneliness. 7/n

A lot of people, including me, were wondering how an IRB could ever approve this study. 

The answer is that no IRB did. The person who ‚Äúsigned off‚Äù on approval from the only ethics board that reviewed it had resigned three years earlier. His signature was used without his knowledge.
As it was before, so it is now and will be forevermore: the real art underlying CS is learning how to manage complexity.
